history.content: Unless you are looking at a very specific role at certain companies, such as Risk Analysis at a cyber-security company or roles at Nvidia or Canonical or something, then you will not be at a significant disadvantage. Most of the time. I don't think New Grad engineers are not expected to have a strong emphasis in any particular field besides the standard algorthms, data structures, and maybe system design.

children.subject: My view on 162 is: if you are able to easily read and understand the textbook, you will also be able to easily do the projects. The class is worth taking.

I'm also in the situation that SWE is not my number 1 choice, but is a backup. I'm also trying to avoid taking 162 (already taking 161, but only since it interested me more and the class is quite enjoyable really). Things I've heard is that 162 is really useful for SWE, but that the most useful concepts may be learned from reading the textbook as much of 162 is a lot of project work and hence C debugging etc. You are probably fine if you don't take 162, just make sure to read up on the relevant concepts at some point since it may come up in your interview and it's generally at least good to be aware of some of them on the job, if you don't have to build anything directly interacting with the OS, that is.

While I don't think you'll be at 'disadvantage' in terms of job search, I strongly believe everyone should have some exposure to security concepts if you're going to be doing anything in the real world!

Disagree. Modern interviews are increasingly adding OS concepts. In fact, my interview(s) for my current summer internship were all systems questions (distributed hash table, implement readers/writers lock, implement efficient/specialized database).

I said most interviews though, but yeah you're right. From my experience, swe roles do ask a tiny bit of 162 concepts, though as you said some companies like specialized aws teams, databricks, okta, dropbox do ask really detailed concepts from 161 and 162. From the mle interviews I've had usually you are spared from these topics though.

Most swe interviews usually don't go as far to 161/162 concepts.

However, I think taking those classes lower your learning curve significantly while you are in your first new grad job.

if u have a strong rec letter in line (aite chance at landing 5th years) and wana to mathy stuff as a career (not pure swe), imo go balls to walls on getting ur masters cuz u’ll regret sacrificing what u wanted for the safer, less preferred option. but that being said after u submit ur apps u should def interview prep hard while u wait for ur app results (in case u aren’t accepted).

ofc if u wana do swe full time then just go into industry

There is no need to take about 127 and 110, especially not in the same semester. They cover a lot of the same mathematical content. Also, if you have taken 189, 127 is also less important. If you want to develop mathematical maturity, I would say take 110 and then pick either 161 or 162 depending on what interests you.

history.content:
Hey everyone,

Looking for some course advice for my final semester (this fall). In general, I enjoy research and mathy CS (liked 126 and 189) and I'm planning on applying to the 5th year masters program, so I want to take eecs 127 and math 110 to round out my mathematical foundation for grad school. 

However, I've heard the program is becoming very competitive, and if I don't get in, it's very likely I'll be doing SWE after graduation. In this case, I'm concerned that I might be disadvantaged without ever having taken 161 or 162 (which could replace 127/110). I'm doing a backend internship this summer which should supplant the coding experience you get from 161/162, but I'll lose out on the knowledge of security and OS.

There might not be a "right" answer but can anyone give their opinion on which set of courses to take, or if I'm thinking about this the right way? Thank you!
history.subject: SWE without 161/162?
